subject: Re: junit & broadvision
msgSnippet: ... used to ... a ... correct that ... the ... First thanks thanks for a response to my question. I know Junit was developed with unit testing of everything
messageBody:
> JUnit /can/ be used to test anything that is Java, it can even be
used to
> test non-Java apps. The proof of whether or not it is suited to
a
> particular need is an exercise left to the reader. You are
correct that
> your question is very broad. A better answer may come if you take
the
> time to define your needs to us.

First thanks thanks for a response to my question.

I know Junit was developed with unit testing of everything that is
java. The basic concepts and methods of testing strings, hash tables
and other objects created in classes and their methods is not that
hard to understand.

But the question I didn't ask and should have is about testing
server objects. BroadVision has many server objects (Site, User,
Session, HttpRequests, ...) that are passed to the classes and are
needed to perform the logic contained in them. I have been reading
about HttpUnit and ServletUnit and it seems that if I am going to
write successful unit tests employing JUnit, I am going to have to
somehow get these objects from the server. So while I can write a
TestSuite which has some values that I will be testing against, how
am I suppose to get the BV Server to supply the objects that only A
BV server can provide? Do I need to integrate Cactus, or one of the
other Unit testing modules to make this happen? I guess I am looking
for any suggestions or recommendations of what will provide the
server interaction with Junit. While hard coding values in a test
suite provides adequate testing for some things it won't cut it for
dynamic server objects that can't be replicated by static values.
The last thing I want to do is strip classes of the logic that
require those values because it couldn't possibly provide adequate
or realistic testing scenarios or environments that I am testing for
in the first place.


Eric
